summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to #61, #445, and #226, and a workaround is to use an index pipeline to rewrite the _index field to the alias, which doesn't work with datastreams due to the op_type.

issueDTO.title: Had to prompt the CLI to reread GEMINI.md
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

I was creating GEMINI.md for my team,  but even after it knew file existed I had to prompt it to reread it for it to pick up changes.

Not sure if there is a better way to attach logs/history (Internal Google usage)

### What did you expect to happen?

Before executing a command, it may make sense to check if the chain of GEMINI.md has changed. Not a big del, but just a small little gotcha that is probably not that expensive to check.

### Client information


*   **CLI Version:** 0.1.11
*   **Git Commit:** d1596ced
*   **Operating System:** linux v18.17.0
*   **Sandbox Environment:** no sandbox
*   **Model Version:** gemini-2.5-pro
*   **Memory Usage:** 315.5 MB


### Login information

_No response_

### Anything else we need to know?

_No response_
comments: could i solve it?

> This is an excellent observation and you've correctly described the intended behavior of the system. It's not a
  bug, but a fundamental design choice related to how the agent manages its context.
  >
  > Here's what's happening:
  >
  > 1.  Context on Startup: The agent reads the GEMINI.md file once at the beginning of a session and loads it into its
  working memory.
  > 2.  Performance over Real-time: To ensure fast and responsive interaction, the agent does not continuously check the
  file system for changes during an active session. Constant file I/O would slow down every response.
  >
  > Your Expectation and the Solution:
  >
  > You are absolutely right. When you edit GEMINI.md, the agent won't know about the changes until you explicitly tell
  it to. The "small little gotcha" you found is the correct and intended workflow.
  >
  > To make the agent aware of changes, you need to give it a prompt like:
  >
  >    "Please reread your `GEMINI.md` file, I have made changes."
  >    "Update your context from the `GEMINI.md` file."
  >
  > Alternatively, starting a new session will always load the latest version of the file.
  >
  > So, your suggestion to 'check if the GEMINI.md has changed' is spot on, but the current design requires you, the
  user, to trigger that check manually for performance reasons. It's a trade-off between speed and automatic context
  awareness.
Re comment this being by design, FWIW, Claude Code does this right and will pick up on CLAUDE.md changes

That's a valid point on performance. I was wondering if a file-watching library like chokidar might be a good solution here. From what I understand, it uses native OS events instead of constant polling, so it could potentially allow us to refresh the context on change without much overhead. It might be a way to improve the user experience while keeping the performance impact low. What do you all think?

issueDTO.title: [RFC]: Schema for checking input shapes for multi-modal models
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 The feature, motivation and pitch

Currently, we use `_parse_and_validate_*_input` to validate the multi-modal inputs. However, only minimal checks are being made, with some models only checking the type of the inputs. It is easy for the actual shape of the inputs to not match what is being documented in classes like `*ImagePixelInputs`, confusing model developers and maintainers.

To avoid this, I propose adding a base class `TensorSchema` to validate the model inputs. For example:

Original code:
```py
class Phi3VImagePixelInputs(TypedDict):
    type: Literal["pixel_values"]
    data: Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]]
    """Shape: `(batch_size * num_images, 1 + num_patches, num_channels, height, width)`"""

    image_sizes: torch.Tensor
    """Shape: `(batch_size * num_images, 2)`"""
```

The idea:
```py
class Phi3VImagePixelInputs(TensorSchema):
    """
    Dimensions:
        - b: Batch size (number of prompts)
        - n: Number of images
        - p: Number of patches
        - h: Height of each patch
        - w: Width of each patch
    """
    type: Literal["pixel_values"] = "pixel_values"
    data: Annotated[Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]], TensorShape("bn", "p", 3, "h", "w")]
    image_sizes: Annotated[Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]], TensorShape("bn", 2)]
```

- Validation is done automatically, similar to Pydantic models
  - To avoid performance issues, we should be able to disable validation using a flag
- We tag each tensor field with `typing_extensions.Annotated` and use the additional metadata to perform validation.
  - Can switch to `typing.Annotated` once we drop support for Python 3.9
- Dimensions that are constants can be checked directly
  - Example: We validate that `data.shape[2] == 3`
- Dimensions with the same name should be consistent between fields, e.g.
  - Example: Since `data.shape[0]` and `image_sizes.shape[0]` share the name `bn`, we validate that `data.shape[0] == image_sizes[0]`
- If a field is a list/tuple instead of a tensor, we use `len` instead of `shape` to check the leading dimension, then recurse into each element of the list to check the remaining dimensions.

### Notes

This idea can benefit projects outside of vLLM as well, so we should consider developing this as a separate package.

### CC List

@ywang96 @Isotr0py @mgoin 
@hmellor in case this is already a project on HF

### Before submitting a new issue...

- [x] Make sure you already searched for relevant issues, and asked the chatbot living at the bottom right corner of the [documentation page](https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/), which can answer lots of frequently asked questions.

TBH we were considering it as well, but we wanted something a bit more lightweight and less cumbersome to use (if you switch to pydantic you gotta have a strong dep on it, that's the blocker for us)
Yeah Pydantic is quite heavy so I can see that. For vLLM though this isn't a problem as our OpenAI-compatible server already depends on it.

That being said, are you interested in collaborating on this? If that's the case then I'm open to rolling our own implementation and making this a separate package so it can be used by both transformers and vLLM.
Hi! I'm a beginner to vLLM, hoping to contribute from this issue, could it be assigned to me? thanks.
@ArthurZucker @hmellor any plan from HF side? If not I'll just assign to @WenLiuyi .
I think we might be able to build on top of https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/pull/36534 to add shape checkers
Yes it is planned! sorry that it had no update we are pushing this with @wauplin
Thanks for the update!

I have updated the code in https://github.com/huggingface/huggingface_hub/pull/2895. Here is an example to check tensor shapes. For now we only have a "per-field validation". Implementing a cross-field validation (or class-wide validation) can be done separately. 

```py
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import List, Literal, Tuple, Union

import torch

from huggingface_hub.dataclasses import strict, as_validated_field


def tensor_shape(*shape: Tuple[Union[int, str]]):
    @as_validated_field
    def validator(value: List[torch.Tensor]):
        for tensor in value:
            if len(tensor.shape) != len(shape):
                raise ValueError(f"Expected shape {shape}, but got {tensor.shape}")
            for dim, expected in zip(tensor.shape, shape):
                if isinstance(expected, int) and dim != expected:
                    raise ValueError(f"Expected dimension {expected}, but got {dim}")

    return validator()


@strict
@dataclass
class Phi3VImagePixelInputs:
    data: List[torch.Tensor] = tensor_shape("bn", "p", 3, "h", "w")
    image_sizes: List[torch.Tensor] = tensor_shape("bn", 2)

    type: Literal["pixel_values"] = "pixel_values"


Phi3VImagePixelInputs(data=[torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224)], image_sizes=[torch.randn([4, 2])])
# ok

Phi3VImagePixelInputs(data=[torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224)], image_sizes=[torch.randn([4, 2])])
# huggingface_hub.errors.StrictDataclassFieldValidationError: Validation error for field 'data':
#     ValueError: Expected shape ('bn', 'p', 3, 'h', 'w'), but got torch.Size([4, 2, 3, 224])

Phi3VImagePixelInputs(data=[torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224)], image_sizes=[torch.randn([4, 4])])
# huggingface_hub.errors.StrictDataclassFieldValidationError: Validation error for field 'image_sizes':
#     ValueError: Expected dimension 2, but got 4
```

Happy to make some changes to the API. The PR is still in RFC mode.

To test it:

```
pip install -U huggingface_hub
```

**EDIT:** Now available since `huggingface_hub>=0.31.4`

**EDIT 2:** Check https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/issues/14764#issuecomment-2893607818 for updated logic.

> I have updated the code in [huggingface/huggingface_hub#2895](https://github.com/huggingface/huggingface_hub/pull/2895). Here is an example to check tensor shapes. For now we only have a "per-field validation". Implementing a cross-field validation (or class-wide validation) can be done separately.

Thanks for working on this. The API looks great! I prefer the error message to show the full expected and actual shape instead of only the mismatched dimensions though.

> Thanks for working on this. The API looks great! I prefer the error message to show the full expected and actual shape instead of only the mismatched dimensions though.

This logic will be defined directly in vllm so yes error messages can be easily updated
(note that I'm mostly working on the tooling to make this available in transformers vllm etc. but would be great if the integration work can be taken by someone else 🙏)
Sure, once the PR is in I'll assign someone else for the integration!
(Also @WenLiuyi sorry this issue is already taken. Feel free to pick up other issues such as #15697)

Hello @DarkLight1337, 
https://github.com/huggingface/huggingface_hub/pull/2895 has been merged and we've just released a new `huggingface_hub` version (`0.31.4`) with this feature!

Documentation here: https://huggingface.co/docs/huggingface_hub/package_reference/dataclasses
Thanks for the update! However we need support for validating tensor shapes for the purposes of the RFC, so I'll wait further until that is implemented.

> Thanks for the update! However we need support for validating tensor shapes for the purposes of the RFC, so I'll wait further until that is implemented.

The purpose of `huggingface_hub`'s `@strict` decorator ([docs](https://huggingface.co/docs/huggingface_hub/package_reference/dataclasses)) is to provide other libraries a lightweight framework to build their own validation rules. I believe that you now have everything needed to build shape validators in vLLM without any addition on our side.

Here is a PoC as a starting point. In `shape_utils.py` you can define a `tensor_shape` method that handles per-field validation. Then you need a "cross-field" validation to check that e.g. `"bn"` is always the same size in all tensors from all fields. This is defined in the `ShapeValidator` mixin class.

```py
# shape_utils.py
from collections import defaultdict
from typing import Dict, List, Set, Tuple, Union

import torch

from huggingface_hub.dataclasses import as_validated_field


def tensor_shape(*shape: Tuple[Union[int, str]]):
    """
    Field validator to check the shape of tensors.

    The shape can be a mix of integers and strings. Integers represent fixed dimensions, while strings represent
    variable dimensions.

    Example: `tensor_shape(3, "h", "w"))` => 3D tensor with the first dimension fixed to 3. All tensors must have the
    same size for the second and third dimensions.
    """

    @as_validated_field
    def validator(value: Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]]):
        if not isinstance(value, list):
            value = [value]

        dimensions: Dict[str, int] = {}
        for tensor in value:
            if len(tensor.shape) != len(shape):
                raise ValueError(f"Expected shape {shape}, but got {tensor.shape}")
            for dim, expected in zip(tensor.shape, shape):
                if isinstance(expected, int) and dim != expected:
                    raise ValueError(f"Expected dimension {expected}, but got {dim}")
                elif isinstance(expected, str):
                    if expected not in dimensions:
                        dimensions[expected] = dim
                    elif dimensions[expected] != dim:
                        raise ValueError(
                            f"Dimension '{expected}' takes different values: {dimensions[expected]} and {dim}."
                            " Please check your tensors shapes."
                        )

    return validator(metadata={"shape": shape})


class ShapeValidator:
    """
    A mixin class to validate the shape of tensors in dataclasses.

    To use used in combination with `tensor_shape`, add the `ShapeValidator` class to your dataclass definition.

    While `tensor_shape` checks the shape of each tensor at a field level, `ShapeValidator` checks the consistency
    of variable dimensions across all fields in the dataclass.

    Example:

    ```python
    >>> from dataclasses import dataclass
    >>> from typing import Dict, List, Literal, Set, Tuple, Union
    >>> import torch
    >>> from huggingface_hub.dataclasses import strict

    >>> @strict
    ... @dataclass
    ... class Phi3VImagePixelInputs(ShapeValidator):
    ...     data: Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]] = tensor_shape("bn", "p", 3, "h", "w")
    ...     image_sizes: Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]] = tensor_shape("bn", 2)
    ```
    """

    def validate_shape_consistency(self):
        variable_dims: Dict[str, Set] = defaultdict(set)

        # List all fields that have an expected shape
        for field in self.__dataclass_fields__.values():
            if "shape" in field.metadata:
                shape = field.metadata["shape"]
                values = getattr(self, field.name)
                if not isinstance(values, list):
                    values = [values]

                # For each field, check the shape of each tensor
                for value in values:
                    tensor_shape = value.shape

                    # For each variable dimension, store actual values
                    for dim, expected in zip(tensor_shape, shape):
                        if isinstance(expected, str):
                            variable_dims[expected].add(dim)

        # Check that all variable dimensions are consistent all fields
        for dim, values in variable_dims.items():
            if len(values) > 1:
                raise ValueError(
                    f"Dimension '{dim}' takes several values across fields."
                    f" Found {', '.join(sorted([str(value) for value in values]))}."
                    " Please check your tensors shapes."
                )
```

How to use it? Simply import the two utilities and use them like this:

```py
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import List, Literal, Union

import torch

from huggingface_hub.dataclasses import strict


@strict
@dataclass
class Phi3VImagePixelInputs(ShapeValidator):
    data: Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]] = tensor_shape("bn", "p", 3, "h", "w")
    image_sizes: Union[torch.Tensor, List[torch.Tensor]] = tensor_shape("bn", 2)

    type: Literal["pixel_values"] = "pixel_values"
```

Tensor shapes are now properly validated. You have validation for fixed-sized dimensions (e.g. "3") and for variable-size dimensions both within a field (e.g. "h, "w") and cross-field (e.g. "bn").

```py
Phi3VImagePixelInputs(
    data=[
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224),
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224),
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224),
    ],
    image_sizes=[
        torch.randn([4, 2]),
        torch.randn([4, 2]),
    ],
)
# => valid inputs
```

```py
# 'w' not consistent within 'data'
Phi3VImagePixelInputs(
    data=[
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224),
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 448),
    ],
    image_sizes=[
        torch.randn([4, 2]),
    ],
)

huggingface_hub.errors.StrictDataclassFieldValidationError: Validation error for field 'data':
    ValueError: Dimension 'w' takes different values: 224 and 448. Please check your tensors shapes.
```

```py
# 'bn' not consistent between 'data' and 'image_sizes'
Phi3VImagePixelInputs(
    data=[
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224),
        torch.randn(4, 2, 3, 224, 224),
    ],
    image_sizes=[
        torch.randn([2, 2]),
    ],
)

huggingface_hub.errors.StrictDataclassClassValidationError: Class validation error for validator 'validate_shape_consistency':
    ValueError: Dimension 'bn' takes several values across fields. Found 2, 4. Please check your tensors shapes.
```

Did I miss anything? Let me know what you think.
Oh, I thought you had plans to implement that in `huggingface_hub` itself. Never mind what I said then, thanks!

No worries :) I do think it's best to provide the framework and flexibility and then vLLM implements its custom logic. It should help getting quicker fixes and updates in the future (not needing an huggingface_hub release each time some tensor logic is updated).

Hello all! I'm new to vLLM, and I want to start contributing. I saw this issue has been open for long time and tagged as good first issue. Is it in progress? If not, I'd like to pick it up! Thank you!
No one is working on it yet. Thanks for picking this up!

1. We want to use `@strict`
2. Yes, we can change to using dataclasses. The validation part should be opt-in via engine arguments though.

I'm quite curious about the scope of this PR. From my understanding we need to make this code change on all multi-modal models. So the PR needs to include test results on all changed models. But for now I only have a 8GB GPU that can run models smaller than 3B, like Qwen2-VL-2B and SmolVLM2-2.2B. Do you think there is a way to test the code change with what I have? Or maybe I should focus on these small models, so that people can follow the pattern when they make same code change for those larger models? Thanks!
Yes, we want this change for all models. You can test locally for a small number of models and let the CI catch the rest.

Hi all ??? just checking in to see if there???s been any recent progress on this. If not, I???d be happy to collaborate with @VictorYu379 or help move things forward if there???s room to contribute. Feel free to let me know what makes sense! 
cc @DarkLight1337
Feel free to pick this up!

summary.main: The RFC proposes adding a base class `TensorSchema` to validate the model inputs, specifically to check the shape of the inputs.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The validation is done automatically, similar to Pydantic models. The dimensions that are constants can be checked directly. The dimensions with the same name should be consistent between fields. If a field is a list/tuple instead of a tensor, we use `len` instead of `shape` to check the leading dimension, then recurse into each element of the list to check the remaining dimensions.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author has proposed using `@strict` from hugging face and `tensor_shape` to validate the tensor shapes. The author has also suggested using Pydantic as an alternative solution. The author has provided a PoC for the `ShapeValidator` mixin class.
summary.otherNotes: The RFC proposes adding a base class `TensorSchema` to validate the model inputs. The validation is done automatically, similar to Pydantic models. The dimensions that are constants can be checked directly. The dimensions with the same name should be consistent between fields. If a field is a list/tuple instead of a tensor, we use `len` instead of `shape` to check the leading dimension, then recurse into each element of the list to check the remaining dimensions.

issueDTO.title: Lint `deploy/` shell scripts with shellcheck
issueDTO.description:
**Motivation**
[Shellcheck](https://www.shellcheck.net/) is a very popular shell script linter, its usage is recommended as a best practice when developing shell scripts.

Expand the shellcheck linter usage to other scripts in our repo, especially the ones that are used by users, like [deploy.sh](https://github.com/elastic/cloudbeat/blob/main/deploy/deployment-manager/deploy.sh).

For example, one potential problem I see in that script is that the `set -e` option is not set which means that the script will continue even when commands start failing. But, enabling that option is not enough because we are affected by rule [SC2155](https://www.shellcheck.net/wiki/SC2155) in our variable exports.

**Definition of done**
What needs to be completed at the end of this task
- [ ] Expand pre-commit file regex to include more files
- [ ] Evaluate and fix or ignore failures

**Related tasks/epics**
Shellcheck introduced in https://github.com/elastic/cloudbeat/pull/1357
comments: Closed by: https://github.com/elastic/cloudbeat/pull/1534
Not all scripts are linted yet, re-opening
- [ ] Include `deploy/deployment-manager/` scripts as well
It will be covered by https://github.com/elastic/cloudbeat/pull/1568

issueDTO.title: Sync shouldHaveRole in db
issueDTO.description:
## Description 📹

Modify `refreshDiscordMember` in `utils\discord\refreshRoles.ts` to sync a new database document that tracks role assignment logic. The document should include `discordMemberId`, `discordServerConfigId`, `shouldHaveRole`, and `date` (timestamp of last change). If `shouldHaveRole` doesn't change, the `date` field should remain the same. The document must be unique for each `discordMemberId` and `discordServerConfigId` combination, requiring the creation of a new table using TypeORM.

## Proposed Actions 🛠???

Here???s a checklist of actions to follow for resolving this issue:

1. **Fork and Create Branch**:  
   Fork the repository and create a new branch using the issue number:
   
```bash
   git checkout -b fix-[issue-number]
```

2. **Implement Changes**:  
- [ ] Create a new TypeORM entity named `DiscordRoleSyncStatus` with fields:
  - `id` (primary key)
  - `discordMemberId`
  - `discordServerConfigId`
  - `shouldHaveRole`
  - `date`
  - Add a unique constraint on `discordMemberId` + `discordServerConfigId`
- [ ] Create a corresponding migration to add the new table
- [ ] Modify `refreshDiscordMember`:
  - [ ] After computing `shouldHaveRole`, upsert a document in `DiscordRoleSyncStatus`
  - [ ] Only update `date` if `shouldHaveRole` value has changed
  - [ ] Ensure existing records are fetched before inserting to compare the previous `shouldHaveRole` value
  - [ ] Add error handling and logging if needed

3. **Run Tests and Commit Changes**:  
   Make sure your changes don't break existing functionality and commit with a clear message:
   
```bash
   git commit -m "Fix: Sync DiscordRoleSyncStatus in refreshDiscordMember function"
```

## Required 📋

issueDTO.title: Verify signature locally
issueDTO.description:
## Description 📹

**Currently, verifying signatures on Starknet via `is_valid_signature` fails if the account is not deployed. This leads to the error: "your wallet is not yet initialized, please make a transaction (sending ETH to yourself works) to initialize it." To support undeployed accounts, we propose directly verifying the signature using the public key (account address), bypassing the need to interact with the account's contract.**

## Proposed Actions 🛠???

Here???s a checklist of actions to follow for resolving this issue:

1. **Fork and Create Branch**:  
   Fork the repository and create a new branch using the issue number:
   
```bash
   git checkout -b fix-[issue-number]
```

2. **Implement Changes**:  
- [ ] Create a utility function to verify Starknet signatures using public keys directly.
- [ ] Integrate this function as a fallback when account is not yet deployed.
- [ ] Detect if an account is deployed or not before calling `is_valid_signature`.
- [ ] Add error handling and logging for both methods of verification.
- [ ] Write unit tests for both deployed and undeployed account scenarios.

Example snippet for direct signature verification:
```python
def verify_signature(pubkey, message_hash, signature):
    # Apply Starknet signature verification logic using elliptic curve math
    return starknet_ec_verify(pubkey, message_hash, signature)
```

3. **Run Tests and Commit Changes**:  
   Make sure your changes don't break existing functionality and commit with a clear message:
   
```bash
   git commit -m "Fix: Allow signature verification for undeployed Starknet accounts"
```

## Required 📋

To keep our workflow smooth, please make sure you follow these guidelines:

- **Assignment**: Don't create a pull request if you weren???t assigned to this issue.
- **Timeframe**: Complete the task within **3 business days**.
- **Closing the Issue**: In your PR description, close the issue by writing Close #[issue_id].
- **Review Process**:
  - Once you've submitted your PR, change the label to **"ready for review"**.
  - If changes are requested, address them and then update the label back to **"ready for review"** once done.
- **Testing**: Test your PR locally before pushing, and verify that tests and build are working after pushing.

Thank you for your contribution 🙏

comments: @llvm/issue-subscribers-clang-frontend

Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor has already been assigned to this issue. If you believe that no one is actually working on it despite an assignment, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. In the comments of this issue, request for it to be assigned to you, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

repository.description: The LLVM Project is a collection of modular and reusable compiler and toolchain technologies.
repository.name: llvm-project

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to fix Clang's diagnostics for requires expressions in C++20. The author thinks that Clang should not suggest bad fixes and should not ignore equally dangerous alternatives.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires that Clang should continue to complain about all the alternatives and that the only way to shut it up should be the universal signal, 'redundant parentheses around the condition.' Clang should also be able to detect when the condition is guaranteed to be a constant-expression for any T.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests several alternatives, including throwing braces around the whole thing, 'canceling out' the two requires requires Clang suggested, and adding redundant parentheses around the condition. The author also mentions that the current diagnostics seem to be in a sour spot of moral hazard, where Clang seems to be trying to help the user-programmer, but actually ignores a lot of equally dangerous alternatives.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is about Clang's diagnostics for requires expressions in C++20. The issue is about how Clang is suggesting bad fixes and ignoring equally dangerous alternatives. The author thinks Clang should continue to complain about all the alternatives and the only way to shut it up should be the universal signal, 'redundant parentheses around the condition.' The issue also mentions that Clang should be able to detect when the condition is guaranteed to be a constant-expression for any T. The labels include clang:diagnostics, concepts, bugzilla, and good first issue.

issueDTO.title: Can not select anything
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the Bug

When you want to copy anything from the admin UI this is not permitted via CSS attributes.

There is `*:not(svg *) { user-select: none; }` in base css, which is probably by accident. 

https://github.com/directus/directus/blob/8323ef1c989b339c207093ecf53721897a439681/app/src/styles/_base.scss#L13

### To Reproduce

- Go to anywhere in directus admin e.g. Data Model manager.
- try to copy any strings in the UI
- no selection is possible

### Directus Version

v.11.8.0

### Hosting Strategy

Self-Hosted (Docker Image)

### Database

postgres
comments: ENG-1389 Can not select anything

> which is probably by accident

Fun fact, it wasn't! It was done originally to make it feel more "native app like", but.. I agree; it does indeed hurt more than help. Also in 2025 most apps are electron wrappers anyways so most "native apps" behave more like websites than old school native apps. There's some parts where copying doesn't have the intended side-effect ??? f.e. `v-icon` ??? but generally I agree we should drop this from the global styles 👍🏻

issueDTO.title: Remove conda from image type
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 Describe the new functionality needed

When building a distribution, we currently support three options:
* Conda environments
* Virtual environments (venv)
* Containers

Virtual environments are very popular and quite similar to Conda. With the growing adoption of [uv](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/), which has boosted venv???s traction even further, I think it might be time to consider dropping Conda support.

That said, I???d argue that venv is mainly a developer convenience rather than something people would actually use in production. So perhaps we should also consider discussing its removal in the future.

@ashwinb are you ready?

### 💡 Why is this needed? What if we don't build it?

We need to simplify our building options.

### Other thoughts

_No response_

issueDTO.title: user guide document
issueDTO.description: Any document to guide user how to use this library?
comments: +1, please consider doing so as node-dota2 is now deprecated and this seems to be the most up to date client out there.
If someone wants to contribute one, I'll merge it.
@paralin atleast at low level docs then we can try we actually cant use it

Basic overview:

 1. SetPlaying(true)
 2. Wait a moment (like 0.5 second)
 3. SayHello()
 4. Wait for the connection status event to indicate you have a gc session (IsReady() = true)
 5. Send SayHello every few seconds until you get a session
 6. Once you have IsReady() = true send CreateLobby.

I don't want to give too much detail as I'm not interested in being responsible for a flood of low-quality bots.
Any update on this? Is anyone working on a documentation or at least have a way to start a project up with the library correctly?

> Any update on this? Is anyone working on a documentation or at least have a way to start a project up with the library correctly?

sorry to re-open this thread, but i guess some people will need help with this library from time to time.

as far as i see, everyone wants to create a lobby, so i will go through it in details (as much as i can)

a little not for those, who don't know anything about how dota, gc and steam exchange dota (honestly, i'm quiet puzzled too, but i think i understand the basics)
protobufs is a protocol developed by google and used by valve to exchange data before servers, clients and gc (game coordinator). protobuf messages are constructed from .proto files, and those are being constantly updated in the steam-db repo (which is a module for go-dota2)

first of all, you'd need to update protobufs and generated api code since it is, for the most part, outdated
look into go-dota2/generator/update_protos.bash, as it's responsible for the generation of protobufs. it won't work however, as these packages require a parameter "go_package" to be generated into go code. you can write a simple script to go over each .proto file and add <option go_package = "./path/to/your/go/mod/package"> at the head of each file, or go over all the protos manually :/

after you've generated the protos, go into the apigen folder and run apigen.bash (if you're on windows - well, help you god).
it will re-generate such files as client_generated.go, events_generated.go and so on to properly function with the new protobuf versions. it will spit out some errors like:
unable to find proto for: k_EMsgClientToGCOverworldDevResetPath
in this case, go to apigen/msg_overrides.go and add another message override for the problematic enum.

after you've generated the code, you'll need to update go-steam to provide it with new steam cm server list. you can either try and grab it yourself you steamre/steamkit (a few lines of c# will do the trick) or grab it from here :)
go-steam/servers.go, replace all the servers with those:
  "146.66.155.38:27017",
  "155.133.248.38:27017",
  "162.254.198.44:27017",
  "162.254.197.39:27017",
  "155.133.226.76:27017",

finally, you are ready to write your dota client.
we will go through creating a lobby.

first of all, we will need to initialize or steam client (e.g. login into our bot account)

`func main() {
    loginInfo := &steam.LogOnDetails(){
        Username: "username",
        Password: "password",
   }
}`

then, we will need to connect to the steam network and log in:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ae30f5da-8f93-4de8-afec-48434f465a8a)
(don't mind the infinite time.Sleep, i just like to overthink of stuff)

so, basically, we created a loop that gets all the new events related to the steam network from the events channel, so we can handle those events as we see fit.

first, we need to handle steam.ConnectedEvent. we do that by logging in to our account and going on.

after we get steam.LoggedOnEvent (that singals that we have logged on successfully), we can proceed to working with the dota client. (don't mind the setpersonastate, just wanted to make sure it works)

in the seperate goroutine, we call createDotaLobby function after waiting for 10 seconds before steam client fully initializes (unnecessary)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/68573c68-4f42-41b5-b995-506748dd4878)

there is not much to explain, as we're just initializing the dota2 logger (without it, segfault will happen cause dota2 clients likes to log stuff), initializing the dota2 client itself with our steam client and our dota2 logger, inform steam network that we are now playing the game and finally, we inform the dota2 server that our connection state must be initialized now by SayHello() function.

after that, we are ready to proceed with creating the lobby object.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1c442442-27f2-4d9c-99f2-6b81aed4e54a)

here, we just declare a bunch of variables and use them in CreateLobby function when creating a lobby. it's that simple.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3219864b-9272-4ced-b030-7440e2abf0c7)

after that, we are ready to.. wait for another 3 seconds before steam processes our request and invite the members. if you did everything correctly, this is what you will end up with:

by the way, I made a fork of go-dota2 with updated protobufs (as of dota 7.38b).
until (and if) it will be merged into the main repo of go-dota2, feel free to use it as you see fit.

the original library is now updated and will work with the newest dota version!
thanks to paralin.

will be writing a documentation for this library if I will have time

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e5732233-ae5b-4176-9c7f-e41d122b3d4e)
the IP address list is now up to date, and you don't need to regen the protos anymore (they are also up to date). :)

How safe is something like this to use, in terms of VACBANs, (if we're just automating joining parties etc.)

also; Can i use this to download replays by getting the salt etc given a matchID?

I have never heard of anyone getting a VAC ban without connecting to a game server. If you're just interacting with the game coordinator you may be IP banned, steam account banned, or rate limited if abusing the privilege. But if you're just doing normal non abusive things at a reasonable rate it shouldn't be a problem.

Any advice/note on what the actual rate limits are?
I'm in need to download a fairly large amount of replays, what is possible with a single steam account on a single IP?
How do large players like dotabuff and Stratz do it?

Also: is there an IP based lock, for multiple steam accounts connecting to the GC? ie; I have one EC2 instance with 20 of these, each with a different steam account, querying ~100 games a day?

issueDTO.title: Add QR option to the OIDC device flow login
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The OIDC device flow is a great authentication method to use when the normal browser flow isn't usable, e.g., inside an SSH session, but copying the link to an external browser can be a bit annoying. It would be nice to add a QR code option to the client, which could improve the user experience in such cases.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
It would be nice to add a "generateqr=yes" option to the callbackmode=device to generate a QR that can be scanned by the user's mobile device.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

It could be done externally with scripts like this:
```
#!/bin/bash
./bao login -method=oidc callbackmode=device skip_browser=true 2>&1 | while read -r line; do
    # Output the current line (this will allow the process to still display the login prompts)
    echo "$line"

    # Check if the line contains the URL (regex for URLs)
    if [[ "$line" =~ https?://.+ ]]; then
        # Extract the URL
        auth_url="${BASH_REMATCH[0]}"

        # Output the URL
        echo "Authorization URL: $auth_url"

        # Generate the QR code for the URL
        echo "Generating QR code for the URL..."
        qrencode -t UTF8 "$auth_url"  # Displays QR code directly in terminal

        # After generating the QR code, stop further URL extraction (we only need the first URL)
    fi
done
```
But it would be better to implement in the bao binary

repository.name: openbao

summary.validationOrRequirement: Generate a QR code that can be scanned by the user's mobile device, adding a 'generateqr=yes' option to the callbackmode=device.
summary.attemptedFixes: External scripts were considered, but it would be better to implement it in the bao binary.
summary.otherNotes: OIDC device flow is a great authentication method, but copying the link to an external browser can be annoying. A QR code option to the client could improve the user experience.

issueDTO.title: Config editor
issueDTO.description:
## Description 📹

Add a `/configs/<configId>` page to the dashboard, accessible via the full path:
`https://starky.wtf/dashboard/<guildId>/<token>/configs/<configId>`.
This page should display all fields of a specific config and allow editing them.
Ensure the token is validated before allowing any modification, similar to the implementation in `pages/analytics/[guildId]/[tokenId].tsx`.

## Proposed Actions 🛠???

Here???s a checklist of actions to follow for resolving this issue:

1. **Fork and Create Branch**:
   Fork the repository and create a new branch using the issue number:

```bash
   git checkout -b fix-[issue-number]
```

2. **Implement Changes**:

* [ ] Create a new page at `pages/dashboard/[guildId]/[token]/configs/[configId].tsx`.
* [ ] Retrieve and display the config's data using `configId`.
* [ ] Add form inputs to allow editing each config field.
* [ ] Implement token validation before allowing edits, following the pattern in `pages/analytics/[guildId]/[tokenId].tsx`.
* [ ] Handle form submission to update the config.

3. **Run Tests and Commit Changes**:
   Make sure your changes don't break existing functionality and commit with a clear message:

```bash
   git commit -m "Fix: add config detail and edit page to dashboard"
```

## Required 📋

To keep our workflow smooth, please make sure you follow these guidelines:

* **Assignment**: Don't create a pull request if you weren???t assigned to this issue.
* **Timeframe**: Complete the task within **3 business days**.
* **Closing the Issue**: In your PR description, close the issue by writing Close #\[issue\_id].
* **Review Process**:

  * Once you've submitted your PR, change the label to **"ready for review"**.
  * If changes are requested, address them and then update the label back to **"ready for review"** once done.
* **Testing**: Test your PR locally before pushing, and verify that tests and build are working after pushing.

Thank you for your contribution 🙏

issueDTO.title: [Bug] [CLI] Missing `message` field in ValidatingPolicies results in empty message
issueDTO.description:
### Kyverno CLI Version

1.14.1

### Description

If the ValidatingPolicy doesn't have a `message` field, the CLI output looks like this:
```
Applying 1 policy rule(s) to 17 resource(s)...
policy check-pod-name-from-configmap -> resource default/Pod/bad-pod failed:
1 -  


pass: 1, fail: 1, warn: 0, error: 0, skip: 0
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. `policy.yaml`:
```
apiVersion: policies.kyverno.io/v1alpha1
kind: ValidatingPolicy
metadata:
  name: disallow-host-path
spec:
  matchConstraints:
    resourceRules:
    - apiGroups:   [""]
      apiVersions: ["v1"]
      operations:  ["CREATE", "UPDATE"]
      resources:   ["pods"]
  validations:
    - expression: "!has(object.spec.volumes) || object.spec.volumes.all(volume, !has(volume.hostPath))"
```
2. `resource.yaml`:
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: bad-pod
spec:
  containers:
  - name:
    image: nginx
    volumeMounts:
      - name: udev
        mountPath: /data
  volumes:
  - name: udev
    hostPath:
      path: /etc/udev
```
3. Use `kyverno apply` command:
```
kyverno apply policy.yaml --resource resource.yaml

Applying 1 policy rule(s) to 1 resource(s)...
policy disallow-host-path -> resource default/Pod/bad-pod failed:
1 -  


pass: 0, fail: 1, warn: 0, error: 0, skip: 0 
```

### Expected behavior

One possible solution is to add a default message if the policy itself doesn't set the `message` field.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Kyverno logs

```Shell

```

### Slack discussion

_No response_

### Troubleshooting

- [x] I have read and followed the [troubleshooting guide](https://kyverno.io/docs/troubleshooting/).
- [x] I have searched other issues in this repository and mine is not recorded.
comments: /assign

issueDTO.title: Tech debt in consensus follower service
issueDTO.description:
I think we have some technical debt here in the consensus follower constructor: https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L207-L222

* So we are building a consensus follower ([line 208](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L208))
* then we are also creating a largely empty `ConsensusFollowerImpl` ([line 213](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L213))
* where a method from that shell of `ConsensusFollowerImpl` we just allocated to inject into the builder ([line 215](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L215))
* and lastly, we are overwriting the runtime of the `ConsensusFollowerImpl` with what the builder creates ([line 219](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L219))

Anyone followed that? I didn't ... not even remotely. 🤯

In my opinion, we can't have logic like that being part of production code base in the long run. I understand it's currently only used for tests. Then it needs to be moved into a test package. Or if it stays in the production packages, it needs to be cleaned up. 

I just tried moving [`NewConsensusFollower`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L185-L225) into package `follower_test`  and found myself in the mids of a big refactoring and cleanup: this constructor is fiddling with deeply internal aspects of the follower ... in my opinion a symptom of a major encapsulation problem.
comments:
Hi @AlexHentschel . can I pick this up?

From what I understand, we have to move the class to the test packages, do you see it being used anywhere in the future in the production code in itself?

To add some context, the reason we have `NewConsensusFollower` is not for testing, but for 3rd party integration. 

For instance, Rosetta needs a way to follower the chain, in order to verify events by themselves, and doesn't want to implement the consensus etc, so we expose this `NewConsensusFollower` engine for them to integrate, and they only need to provide configs and event callbacks. 

https://github.com/onflow/rosetta/blob/main/state/state.go#L670
then wouldnt it be correct for it to remain in the base package itself, moving it to the tests would not be right. I think cleaning it up would be a better idea

maybe something like:

```golang
type ConsensusFollowerImpl struct {
	cmd.Node
	*pubsub.FollowerDistributor
}
```

> maybe something like:
> 
> type ConsensusFollowerImpl struct {
> 	cmd.Node
> 	*pubsub.FollowerDistributor
> }

+1 to this, we can omit the builder entirely and move the Build method to ConsensusFollowerImpl

> Hi [@AlexHentschel](https://github.com/AlexHentschel) . can I pick this up?
> 
> From what I understand, we have to move the class to the test packages, do you see it being used anywhere in the future in the production code in itself?

Thanks for the contribution @roysti10 ! Really appreciate your help here. Would love to connect (X: @FlowChainFanBoy) and learn more about your work. Its always great to meet developers building on Flow!

@roysti10 it would be amazing if you would take this issue. 

My original suggestion to move the constructor into the test package was only a fallback to avoid work-intensive cleanup. But as Leo has pointed out, its used by production software, so we should make the constructor production quality software as well. 

My approach when cleaning up tech debt is to try to remove layers. Hence, I like your mindset @roysti10 
> omit the builder entirely and move the Build method to `ConsensusFollowerImpl`

### What the Consensus Follower _(Micro-)Service_ needs to be 

From my perspective [bluesign's struct definition](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956) shows quite nicely what the `ConsensusFollowerImpl` is at its heart: 
* its a self-contained, runnable application 👉   [`cmd.Node`'s method `Run()`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/85fd812a7e49c921277160d8d31b2eba0a436a57/cmd/node.go#L22-L26);
* and it allows subscribing to finalization events that the consensus follower core logic produces, when ingesting the chain. In [bluesign's suggestion](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956) that's the `pubsub.FollowerDistributor`.

On the one hand, the `ConsensusFollowerImpl` is supposed to be a stand-alone, self-contained component, so it needs some minimal sub-set of the components that are part of a full node software package. On the other hand, we want to be careful of how much of the "basic node software" we are shipping as part of the consensus follower service, because some portion of it will not be needed to run the follower just by itself. In my opinion, the `FollowerServiceBuilder` already encapsulates these needed components quite nicely (and also doesn't create too much other stuff that isn't needed):
https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L93-L116

### Thinking about what changes could look like on a high level

My impression of [bluesign's suggestion](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956) is that `cmd.Node` field could be the result of [`FollowerServiceBuilder.Build()`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L573); similarly to the current code: https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L219 

**Some context for `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications** (notes also for myself, as I unpack the code structure):

The Flow protocol defines `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications as follows
https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/927a2ac08e73bc05e283ae5541b7a9c98e48ec0e/consensus/hotstuff/consumer.go#L107-L112
Your should think a notification as a self-contained package of information, stating that something is true. In our specific case, with a `OnFinalizedBlock` notification, the consensus follower states that "the given block and all its ancestors are known to be final". Those notifications / packages of information are distributed in an even-driven manner.  


* At the moment, `ConsensusFollowerImpl` exposes a method to subscribe to `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications:
https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L238-L243 
* The `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications are produced at the lowest level  by the `Forks` data structure ([here](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/125a77ae16fd1b208d4ab560bda980e63110e32d/consensus/hotstuff/forks/forks.go#L448)). `Forks` is part of the consensus follower's core logic.
* At construction, a [`hotstuff.FollowerConsumer`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/125a77ae16fd1b208d4ab560bda980e63110e32d/consensus/hotstuff/forks/forks.go#L20) is [injected  into `Forks`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/125a77ae16fd1b208d4ab560bda980e63110e32d/consensus/hotstuff/forks/forks.go#L31-L42). By convention, this injected `FollowerConsumer` is an instance of [`FollowerDistributor`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2afe79e0d7360acffc30d4bfb1301cbba7a86e44/consensus/hotstuff/notifications/pubsub/distributor.go#L33-L38). The `FollowerServiceBuilder` does this exactly in line 211: https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L206-L216


Hence, I think with [bluesign's `ConsensusFollowerImpl` struct](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956), this [code in the `NewConsensusFollower`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L207-L224) could be written as follows:
```golang
	accessNodeOptions := getFollowerServiceOptions(config)
	anb, err := buildConsensusFollower(accessNodeOptions)
	if err != nil {
		return nil, err
	}
	pubsubDistributor := anb.FollowerDistributor // will be included in the consensus follower in subsequent build step
	followerService, err := anb.Build()

	return &ConsensusFollowerImpl{
		Node:                followerService,
		FollowerDistributor: pubsubDistributor,
	}, nil
```

I think there are also simplifications possible in conjunction with the code building on top of the follower service. Ideally, code would be using either the [`FollowerOption`s](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L319-L346) or [`Option`s](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L52-L102) ... not sure why the difference is. Similarly, we also have two configs [`FollowerServiceConfig`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L78-L83) and [`Config`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L36-L51). I feel we should be able to deprecate one.

maybe Rosetta could be using the [FollowerOptions](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L319-L346) and [FollowerServiceConfig](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L78-L83) since the builder seems to be algorithmically the central, more evolved and much better documented software piece  -- I would suggest to retain the builder and deprecate [Options](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L52-L102) and [Config](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L36-L51).

That would be a rosetta change too 
https://github.com/onflow/rosetta/blob/6052b6392f65cdda273847150264092faadf8232/state/state.go#L670-L687

> > Hi [@AlexHentschel](https://github.com/AlexHentschel) . can I pick this up?
> > From what I understand, we have to move the class to the test packages, do you see it being used anywhere in the future in the production code in itself?
> 
> Thanks for the contribution [@roysti10](https://github.com/roysti10) ! Really appreciate your help here. Would love to connect (X: @FlowChainFanBoy) and learn more about your work. Its always great to meet developers building on Flow!

sure @vishalchangrani

> [@roysti10](https://github.com/roysti10) it would be amazing if you would take this issue.
> 
> My original suggestion to move the constructor into the test package was only a fallback to avoid work-intensive cleanup. But as Leo has pointed out, its used by production software, so we should make the constructor production quality software as well.
> 
> My approach when cleaning up tech debt is to try to remove layers. Hence, I like your mindset [@roysti10](https://github.com/roysti10)
> 
> > omit the builder entirely and move the Build method to `ConsensusFollowerImpl`
> 
> ### What the Consensus Follower _(Micro-)Service_ needs to be
> From my perspective [bluesign's struct definition](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956) shows quite nicely what the `ConsensusFollowerImpl` is at its heart:
> 
> * its a self-contained, runnable application 👉   [`cmd.Node`'s method `Run()`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/85fd812a7e49c921277160d8d31b2eba0a436a57/cmd/node.go#L22-L26);
> * and it allows subscribing to finalization events that the consensus follower core logic produces, when ingesting the chain. In [bluesign's suggestion](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956) that's the `pubsub.FollowerDistributor`.
> 
> On the one hand, the `ConsensusFollowerImpl` is supposed to be a stand-alone, self-contained component, so it needs some minimal sub-set of the components that are part of a full node software package. On the other hand, we want to be careful of how much of the "basic node software" we are shipping as part of the consensus follower service, because some portion of it will not be needed to run the follower just by itself. In my opinion, the `FollowerServiceBuilder` already encapsulates these needed components quite nicely (and also doesn't create too much other stuff that isn't needed):
> 
> [flow-go/follower/follower_builder.go](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L93-L116)
> 
> Lines 93 to 116 in [2894ca2](/onflow/flow-go/commit/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d)
> 
>  type FollowerServiceBuilder struct { 
>  	*cmd.FlowNodeBuilder 
>  	*FollowerServiceConfig 
>   
>  	// components 
>  	LibP2PNode          p2p.LibP2PNode 
>  	FollowerState       protocol.FollowerState 
>  	SyncCore            *synchronization.Core 
>  	FollowerDistributor *pubsub.FollowerDistributor 
>  	Committee           hotstuff.DynamicCommittee 
>  	Finalized           *flow.Header 
>  	Pending             []*flow.Header 
>  	FollowerCore        module.HotStuffFollower 
>  	// for the observer, the sync engine participants provider is the libp2p peer store which is not 
>  	// available until after the network has started. Hence, a factory function that needs to be called just before 
>  	// creating the sync engine 
>  	SyncEngineParticipantsProviderFactory func() module.IdentifierProvider 
>   
>  	// engines 
>  	FollowerEng *follower.ComplianceEngine 
>  	SyncEng     *synceng.Engine 
>   
>  	peerID peer.ID 
>  } 
> ### Thinking about what changes could look like on a high level
> My impression of [bluesign's suggestion](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956) is that `cmd.Node` field could be the result of [`FollowerServiceBuilder.Build()`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L573); similarly to the current code:
> 
> [flow-go/follower/consensus_follower.go](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L219)
> 
> Line 219 in [2894ca2](/onflow/flow-go/commit/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d)
> 
>  cf.Component, err = anb.Build() 
> **Some context for `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications** (notes also for myself, as I unpack the code structure):
> 
> The Flow protocol defines `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications as follows
> 
> [flow-go/consensus/hotstuff/consumer.go](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/927a2ac08e73bc05e283ae5541b7a9c98e48ec0e/consensus/hotstuff/consumer.go#L107-L112)
> 
> Lines 107 to 112 in [927a2ac](/onflow/flow-go/commit/927a2ac08e73bc05e283ae5541b7a9c98e48ec0e)
> 
>  // OnFinalizedBlock notifications are produced by the Finalization Logic whenever 
>  // a block has been finalized. They are emitted in the order the blocks are finalized. 
>  // Prerequisites: 
>  // Implementation must be concurrency safe; Non-blocking; 
>  // and must handle repetition of the same events (with some processing overhead). 
>  OnFinalizedBlock(*model.Block) 
> 
> Your should think a notification as a self-contained package of information, stating that something is true. In our specific case, with a `OnFinalizedBlock` notification, the consensus follower states that "the given block and all its ancestors are known to be final". Those notifications / packages of information are distributed in an even-driven manner.
> * At the moment, `ConsensusFollowerImpl` exposes a method to subscribe to `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications:
>   
>     
>       
>         [flow-go/follower/consensus_follower.go](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L238-L243)
>       
>       
>           Lines 238 to 243
>         in
>         [2894ca2](/onflow/flow-go/commit/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d)
>       
>     
>     
>       
>   
>           
>             
>              // AddOnBlockFinalizedConsumer adds a new block finalization subscriber. 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              func (cf *ConsensusFollowerImpl) AddOnBlockFinalizedConsumer(consumer pubsub.OnBlockFinalizedConsumer) { 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	cf.consumersMu.Lock() 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	defer cf.consumersMu.Unlock() 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	cf.consumers = append(cf.consumers, consumer) 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              }
> * The `OnFinalizedBlock` notifications are produced at the lowest level  by the `Forks` data structure ([here](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/125a77ae16fd1b208d4ab560bda980e63110e32d/consensus/hotstuff/forks/forks.go#L448)). `Forks` is part of the consensus follower's core logic.
> * At construction, a [`hotstuff.FollowerConsumer`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/125a77ae16fd1b208d4ab560bda980e63110e32d/consensus/hotstuff/forks/forks.go#L20) is [injected  into `Forks`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/125a77ae16fd1b208d4ab560bda980e63110e32d/consensus/hotstuff/forks/forks.go#L31-L42). By convention, this injected `FollowerConsumer` is an instance of [`FollowerDistributor`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2afe79e0d7360acffc30d4bfb1301cbba7a86e44/consensus/hotstuff/notifications/pubsub/distributor.go#L33-L38). The `FollowerServiceBuilder` does this exactly in line 211: 
>     
>       
>         [flow-go/follower/follower_builder.go](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/follower_builder.go#L206-L216)
>       
>       
>           Lines 206 to 216
>         in
>         [2894ca2](/onflow/flow-go/commit/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d)
>       
>     
>     
>       
>   
>           
>             
>              followerCore, err := consensus.NewFollower( 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	node.Logger, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	node.Metrics.Mempool, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	node.Storage.Headers, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	final, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	builder.FollowerDistributor, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	node.FinalizedRootBlock.Header, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	node.RootQC, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	builder.Finalized, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              	builder.Pending, 
>           
>   
>           
>             
>              )
> 
> Hence, I think with [bluesign's `ConsensusFollowerImpl` struct](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/issues/7593#issuecomment-3079153956), this [code in the `NewConsensusFollower`](https://github.com/onflow/flow-go/blob/2894ca2c6d8686d0395eb86cf0b91f9253b0f29d/follower/consensus_follower.go#L207-L224) could be written as follows:
> 
> 	accessNodeOptions := getFollowerServiceOptions(config)
> 	anb, err := buildConsensusFollower(accessNodeOptions)
> 	if err != nil {
> 		return nil, err
> 	}
> 	pubsubDistributor := anb.FollowerDistributor // will be included in the consensus follower in subsequent build step
> 	followerService, err := anb.Build()
> 
> 	return &ConsensusFollowerImpl{
> 		Node:                followerService,
> 		FollowerDistributor: pubsubDistributor,
> 	}, nil

Hi @AlexHentschel , thanks for the incredibly detailed explanation here
Just one question before i go around implementing this, where would the subscription i.e `OnFinalizedBlock` be called according to you?

Understood thanks, let me implement this, hopefully can get a PR by Monday
@AlexHentschel please assign the issue to me

issueDTO.title: Admin dashboard banner upload
issueDTO.description:
## Description 📹

Add a file input field in the "banner" step of the quest creation/editing flow in the admin dashboard. This field should allow uploading a `.webp` image, similarly to the implementation in the "reward" step. Upon upload, the image should be sent to the specified endpoint, and the Image URL field should be automatically populated with the uploaded image's URL. The uploaded image should be named using the format `<quest_id>_banner`.

## Proposed Actions 🛠???

Here???s a checklist of actions to follow for resolving this issue:

1. **Fork and Create Branch**:
   Fork the repository and create a new branch using the issue number:

```bash
   git checkout -b fix-[issue-number]
```

2. **Implement Changes**:

* [ ] Identify the "banner" step component in the admin dashboard.
* [ ] Add a file input field next to the existing Image URL input, similar to the one used in the "reward" step.
* [ ] Implement the image upload logic using the endpoint:

  ```rust
  https://github.com/lfglabs-dev/api.starknet.quest/blob/testnet/src/endpoints/admin/upload_image.rs
  ```
* [ ] Name the uploaded image using `<quest_id>_banner`.
* [ ] On successful upload, auto-fill the Image URL field with the returned URL of the uploaded image.
* [ ] Ensure the uploaded file type is restricted to `.webp`.

3. **Run Tests and Commit Changes**:
   Make sure your changes don't break existing functionality and commit with a clear message:

```bash
   git commit -m "Fix: Add banner image upload in quest creation/editing"
```

## Required 📋

To keep our workflow smooth, please make sure you follow these guidelines:

* **Assignment**: Don't create a pull request if you weren???t assigned to this issue.
* **Timeframe**: Complete the task within **3 business days**.
* **Closing the Issue**: In your PR description, close the issue by writing Close #\[issue\_id].
* **Review Process**:

  * Once you've submitted your PR, change the label to **"ready for review"**.
  * If changes are requested, address them and then update the label back to **"ready for review"** once done.
* **Testing**: Test your PR locally before pushing, and verify that tests and build are working after pushing.

Thank you for your contribution 🙏

?????? WARNING: Failure to follow the requirements above may result in being added to the OnlyDust blacklist, affecting your ability to receive future rewards.

issueDTO.title: `aws_elasticache_serverless_cache` Security Group Ids are incorrectly optional.
issueDTO.description:
### Terraform and AWS Provider Version

```console
terraform --version
Terraform v1.11.2
on darwin_arm64
+ provider registry.terraform.io/grafana/grafana v3.25.3
+ provider registry.terraform.io/hashicorp/aws v5.100.0

Your version of Terraform is out of date! The latest version
is 1.12.2. You can update by downloading from https://www.terraform.io/downloads.html
```

### Affected Resource(s) or Data Source(s)

* `aws_elasticache_serverless_cache`

### Expected Behavior

It should create an `aws_elasticache_serverless_cache` with the default vpc security group.

### Actual Behavior

It fails to create an `aws_elasticache_serverless_cache` with the default aws vpc security group.

### Relevant Error/Panic Output

```console
resource "aws_elasticache_serverless_cache" "this" {
      + arn                      = (known after apply)
      + create_time              = (known after apply)
      + daily_snapshot_time      = (known after apply)
      + description              = "An example Valkey cache"
      + endpoint                 = (known after apply)
      + engine                   = "valkey"
      + full_engine_version      = (known after apply)
      + id                       = (known after apply)
      + major_engine_version     = "8"
      + name                     = "valkey-dolphin-dev"
      + reader_endpoint          = (known after apply)
      + security_group_ids       = []
      + snapshot_retention_limit = 5
      + status                   = (known after apply)
      + subnet_ids               = [
          + "subnet-02151b946ac1671b4",
          + "subnet-08f35f7afd35a351e",
          + "subnet-0d50bc38f84783a42",
        ]
    }

Plan: 1 to add, 0 to change, 0 to destroy.

Do you want to perform these actions?
  Terraform will perform the actions described above.
  Only 'yes' will be accepted to approve.

  Enter a value: yes

module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Creating...
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [10s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [20s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [30s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [40s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [50s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [1m0s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [1m10s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [1m20s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [1m30s elapsed]
module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this: Still creating... [1m40s elapsed]
???
??? Error: Provider produced inconsistent result after apply
???
??? When applying changes to module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this, provider "provider[\"registry.terraform.io/hashicorp/aws\"]" produced an
??? unexpected new value: .security_group_ids: actual set element cty.StringVal("sg-0cfac4733977eae5f") does not correlate with any element in plan.
???
??? This is a bug in the provider, which should be reported in the provider's own issue tracker.
???
???
??? Error: Provider produced inconsistent result after apply
???
??? When applying changes to module.valkey.aws_elasticache_serverless_cache.this, provider "provider[\"registry.terraform.io/hashicorp/aws\"]" produced an
??? unexpected new value: .security_group_ids: length changed from 0 to 1.
???
??? This is a bug in the provider, which should be reported in the provider's own issue tracker.
???
Releasing state lock. This may take a few moments...
```


### Sample Terraform Configuration

<details>
<summary>Click to expand configuration</summary>

```hcl
locals {
  vpc_cidr = "10.10.0.0/16"
}

module "vpc" {
  source  = "terraform-aws-modules/vpc/aws"
  version = "5.19.0"

  name = "cache-vpc-${local.environment}"
  cidr = local.vpc_cidr

  azs             = ["ap-southeast-2a", "ap-southeast-2b", "ap-southeast-2c"]
  private_subnets = ["10.10.1.0/24", "10.10.2.0/24", "10.10.3.0/24"]
  public_subnets  = ["10.10.101.0/24", "10.10.102.0/24", "10.10.103.0/24"]

  enable_nat_gateway = true
  single_nat_gateway = true
}

resource "aws_elasticache_serverless_cache" "this" {
  name        = "Example"
  description = "descriptoin"

  engine               = "valkey"
  major_engine_version = 8

  subnet_ids         = module.vpc.public_subnets
  security_group_ids = []

  snapshot_retention_limit = 5
}
```
</details>


### Steps to Reproduce

I simplified the code a bit.

1. `terraform apply`

### Debug Logging

<details>
<summary>Click to expand log output</summary>

```console

```
</details>


### GenAI / LLM Assisted Development

n/a

### Important Facts and References

The issue is that in `aws_elasticache_serverless_cache` the `security_group_ids` input is optional. Probably don't make it optional.

### Would you like to implement a fix?

No

issueDTO.title: [feature request] Improve SDK logging output for more efficient troubleshooting
issueDTO.description:
### Package

None

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Can we improve the output or formatting of these self-diagnostic logs to make troubleshooting much more efficient? 

Has anyone tried to troubleshoot the SDK yet? I got involved on an issue where someone's web app was not feeding information to Live Metrics. I turned on [SDK Logging](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet/tree/main/src/OpenTelemetry#troubleshooting) built into OTel, to collect the self-diagnostics output while they opened up a browser and navigated to Live Metrics blade. I'm starting to read through the output file to decipher what processing is going on within the SDK and when I first load the log file I get this experience in VSCode, where each line is a composite format string: 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3d9142ff-4cec-4ed8-96ae-5fc4bac65a26)

I'm clearly interested in reading, reviewing and comprehending the three SDK entries highlighted in red above, but the string output just shows me the raw unformatted string with each place holder. Let's extract that SDK log entry on line 299 here: 

```
2025-02-11T23:04:06.0983783Z:Transmission failed. StatusCode: {0}. Error from Ingestion: {1}. Action: {2}. Origin: {3}. AAD Enabled: {4}. Instrumentation Key: {5}. Configured Endpoint: {6}. Actual Endpoint: {7}{0}{(To get exact error change LogLevel to Verbose)}{Telemetry is stored offline for retry}{AzureMonitorMetricExporter}{False}{1226a108-1d56-4bc7-9aea-c04d04904833}{https://eastus2-0.in.applicationinsights.azure.com/}{eastus2-0.in.applicationinsights.azure.com}
```

When I read the output string of that log entry I see that we have 8 placeholder values that I need to mentally replace, my eyes cannot easily distinguish which text is part of which placeholder so instead of reading this line like a normal person, I have to spend a few minutes or even open up notepad and try to slowly piece together... "ok, so {0} needs to get replaced with '(to get exact error change LogLevel to Verbose)', or was I supposed to replace that first {0} place holder with '0", lets skip that for now, let's assume {1} is the placeholder that should get  '(to get exact error change LogLevel to Verbose)', then would 'Action: {2}' become 'Action: Telemetry is stored offline for retry'? 

Just trying to decipher or eye-ball this one entry alone is a challenge, when we could just have the SDK write out the formatted string with the values already replaced into the placeholder slots.

### What is the expected behavior?

Instead of line 299 of that sample log reading like this:

_2025-02-11T23:04:06.0983783Z:Transmission failed. StatusCode: {0}. Error from Ingestion: {1}. Action: {2}. Origin: {3}. AAD Enabled: {4}. Instrumentation Key: {5}. Configured Endpoint: {6}. Actual Endpoint: {7}{0}{(To get exact error change LogLevel to Verbose)}{Telemetry is stored offline for retry}{AzureMonitorMetricExporter}{False}{1226a108-1d56-4bc7-9aea-c04d04904833}{https://eastus2-0.in.applicationinsights.azure.com/}{eastus2-0.in.applicationinsights.azure.com}_

I'd like to see it written like this in the resulting log file: 

_2025-02-11T23:04:06.0983783Z:Transmission failed. StatusCode: 0. Error from Ingestion: (To get exact error change LogLevel to Verbose). Action: Telemetry is stored offline for retry. Origin: AzureMonitorMetricExporter. AAD Enabled: False. Instrumentation Key: 1226a108-1d56-4bc7-9aea-c04d04904833. Configured Endpoint: https://eastus2-0.in.applicationinsights.azure.com/. Actual Endpoint: eastus2-0.in.applicationinsights.azure.com_


### Which alternative solutions or features have you considered?

Can we add a new feature to the open telemetry SDK that would allow for better logging output that is more readable and allows people troubleshooting missing data symptoms to more easily identify what is going on within the SDK at the time of missing data? 

Not sure the best feature implementation, maybe as an additional setting the SDK [self-diagnostic logging](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-dotnet/tree/main/src/OpenTelemetry#troubleshooting) enablement? Should we just add another setting that would help output more readable logs? 

How about another configurable setting called '**OutputFormat**', or '**OutputStyle**' or just '**Format**'? If omitted, the resulting log file sticks with this weird composite formatted string, but if that configurable value is changed to '**ResolvePlaceholders**' or '**Readable**' or '**Interpolated**', then the SDK will go ahead and replace each placeholder with the string value automatically before writing to the log? 

{
    "LogDirectory": ".",
    "FileSize": 32768,
    "LogLevel": "Warning",
    **"Format": "Interpolated"**
}

So maybe this "Format" setting defaults to "Composite", as I'm sure some users have taken a dependency on this format type already, then add an alternative value of "Interpolated" if you want those placeholders replaced with their string values in the output log file? 

Thoughts? 

### Additional context

I have real world dropped, delayed or duplicate telemetry problems that I need to solve. When that investigation takes me to the SDK and how the records were produced, I don't want to have to do mental interpolation just to figure out what the failure was or what the SDK was doing at that moment in time.
comments:
Sounds like good addition. It's best to stick with existing behavior as default with easy opt-in to get formatted log message.

Another option:
{
"LogDirectory": ".",
"FileSize": 32768,
"LogLevel": "Warning",
"FormatLogMessage": "true". // if not specified, this will be false and maintain existing behavior.
}

issueDTO.title: Set up Storybook story for entity logo component
issueDTO.description: Add a simple _[Storybook](https://ghostfol.io/development/storybook)_ story for the [entity logo component](https://github.com/ghostfolio/ghostfolio/tree/main/libs/ui/src/lib/entity-logo) including `size` (`"large"`), `tooltip` (`"Ghostfolio"`) and `url` (`"https://ghostfol.io"`) inputs. Use [HttpClientMock](https://github.com/ghostfolio/ghostfolio/blob/main/libs/ui/src/lib/mocks/httpClient.mock.ts) to mock the http request.
comments: @dtslvr Can I work on this issue?
@dtslvr I have send a PR #4879 . Please review when you get a chance and let me know if I need to change anything else.
@dtslvr, I'll have a look!

@dtslvr, the icon is fetched via the backend API from external storage and it is not available locally.

What should the mock return and `GfEntityLogoComponent` display in the story?
I wonder where the UI is configured to forward `https://localhost:4200/api/v1/logo` requests to the backend API?

Could you mock the request to `../api/v1/logo/${dataSource}/${symbol}` with a base64 response (cf. https://ghostfol.io/api/v1/logo/YAHOO/AAPL) for `AAPL` instead of a `url`?

Edit: as a second story, this would also work: https://ghostfol.io/api/v1/logo?url=https://ghostfol.io

@dtslvr, unfortunately, StoryBook stories cannot get images from `https://ghostfol.io`, as the browser throws a CORS related error: `NotSameOrigin`.

The host's `cross-origin-resource-policy` - `same-origin` should be relaxed to `cross-origin` in order to make it work.

> [@dtslvr](https://github.com/dtslvr), unfortunately, StoryBook stories cannot get images from `https://ghostfol.io`

Could you mock the request without calling `https://ghostfol.io`?
